title: Uber's New York bike expansion stymied by dispute over court access
text:
Many riders don’t read the user agreement before signing. City Hall doesn’t appear to read it all that closely, either. | AP Photo Uber's New York bike expansion stymied by dispute over court access

In exchange for expanding its popular bike share program in Staten Island, Uber wants New York City to let it severely limit riders' ability to sue the company.

The de Blasio administration is resisting.

Story Continued Below

Two sources familiar with the matter told POLITICO that the dispute is a major reason New York City and Uber have yet to to sign a new contract to expand the company’s dockless Jump bikes on Staten Island, where they have proven popular since they arrived in summer of 2018. The sources were given anonymity to discuss the matter freely.

“It’s been a bigger success than we thought and we’re trying to work with everybody to expand,” said Staten Island Borough President Jimmy Oddo.

Even as Uber is abandoning its bike share programs in other cities, it has expressed interest in expanding in Staten Island and, ultimately, citywide. The city, too, would like to experiment with a more ambitious dockless-bike pilot on Staten Island, where the city's official bike share operator, Citi Bike, has no presence.

But the “forced arbitration” policy that Uber wants to insert into its user agreements with riders is proving an obstacle. The increasingly commonplace corporate practice prevents users from seeking relief in court when something goes wrong. Consumer advocates deplore it, and so, increasingly, do some politicians.

Presidential candidate Sen. Elizabeth Warren has said she would ban the practice. The House recently passed a bill that would do that, too. House Judiciary Chairman Jerry Nadler (D-N.Y.), who championed the measure, said it would help “the little guy against the giant corporation."

“It’s a terrible problem, because it’s undermining the rule of law,” said George Slover, a senior policy counsel at Consumer Reports. “Whatever protections you think you might have in the law are all trumped because you as the consumer ... are supposedly agreeing to give up all of your rights and take everything to arbitration.”

Forced arbitration can also serve to hide operational problems from government regulators.

“If it’s going to license Uber bike, it needs to know if there are problems with Uber bike,” said David Seligman, the executive director of Towards Justice, a consumer and worker advocacy group.

Asked for comment, Uber spokesperson Harry Hartfield described the company’s discussions with the city as “productive.”

“In the meantime bikes remain active while we try and find a way forward that works for everyone,” he said.

The dominant player in New York City’s bike share economy is Lyft, which owns Citi Bike, a docked bike share system with a contract that it believes precludes competitors from operating in its zones. Its user agreement doesn’t have a forced arbitration clause, though it does contain some contentious provisions of its own.

When a rider signs up to use Citi Bike, that cyclist must sign a user agreement that governs her relationship with the company — including what would happen should she hurt herself while riding a Citi Bike.

According to those provisions, should a rider seek to sue the company, she would first have to “submit the dispute to mandatory mediation held in New York State.” Should the dispute not be resolved through mediation after six months, she could file suit in court.

“Mediation provides our riders with a clear resolution process," said Lyft spokesperson Julie Wood.

Further, should Citi Bike sue a rider and win or secure a settlement, the rider would have to cover the company’s court fees.

Many riders don’t read the user agreement before signing. City Hall doesn’t appear to read it all that closely, either.

Transportation department officials said they were unaware of those two provisions until POLITICO asked them for comment. Officials said they believed a former owner of Citi Bike inserted the provisions into the contact, but it was unable to provide more precision.

“While we are not pleased that the former operator inserted this language into the terms and conditions — we are generally fine with the concept of mediation, as long as there is no cost to the customer,” said New York City Transportation Department spokesperson Scott Gastel. “We take issue with the attorneys’ fees provision and will be addressing both matters with the current operator.”

Mandatory mediation is not forced arbitration. In the former, riders can still access the courts. They just have to wait a while. But consumer advocates say it’s still not ideal.

“We have a system in place to enforce your rights, and that’s through the courts, and courts will often encourage mediation anyways,” Seligman said. “Companies shouldn’t be using the fine print to create different obligations and different legal procedures for themselves.”
description: Even as Uber is abandoning its bike share programs in other cities, it has expressed interest in expanding in Staten Island and, ultimately, citywide.
